abstract:
COVID-19 is a complex disease phenotype where the underlying microbiome could influence morbidity and mortality. Amplicon and metagenomic MinION based sequencing was used to rapidly (within 8 hours) identify SARS-CoV-2 and assess the microbiome in nasopharyngeal swabs obtained from patients with COVID-19 by the ISARIC 4C consortium.
Competing Interest Statement
The authors have declared no competing interest.
affiliations: Wellcome Trust clinical career development fellow, supported by grant number 205228/Z/16/Z
author: Lance Turtle; Calum Semple; Derrick W T Crook; Andrew D. Davidson; Yani Sun; Daniel Carter; J Kenneth Baillie; Zana Mahmood; Catherine Hartley; Julian Druce; Qin Zhao; Richard T Vipond; Xiaofeng Dong; James Cruise; Tom Solomon; Steven T Pullan; Michael B. J. Beadsworth; Muhannad Alruwaili; Julian Alexander Hiscox; En-min Zhou; Debby Bogaert; Lisa Ng; Laurent Renia; Miles W Carroll; Waleed Aljabr; David A Matthews; Shona C Moore; Kevin Bewley; Peter Openshaw; Rebekah Penrice-Randal
title: Amplicon based MinION sequencing of SARS-CoV-2 and metagenomic characterisation of nasopharyngeal swabs from patients with COVID-19

award-group.funding-source: United States Food and Drug Administration

funding.funding-statement: This work was supported by the United States Food and Drug Administration grant number HHSF223201510104C Ebola Virus Disease: correlates of protection, determinants of outcome and clinical management amended to incorporate urgent COVID-19 studies

Recruitment, sample acquisition, transport, laboratory and management costs were supported by the Medical Research Council Protocol for Severe Emerging Infection grant number MC_PC_19025 awarded to J.K.B., M.G.S., and P.J.M.O

This work was supported by Research Center, King Fahad Medical City, Saudi Arabia grant number 019-003 Elucidating the viral biology of MERS-CoV and the host response using high resolution sequencing
